data.title: Cartesian coordinate system - choosing 3d axes for project
data.body:
It would be great to be able to change axes for the whole scene.

Currently 3d axes are
x, z - position on cartesian plane
z - height

In game development it is more common to see xyz order than the current xzy one. It would make working on vectors easier and making it changeable would make it compatible with previous projects.

The con is that coordinate based scripts won't work without changes after copying code to project with different cartesian coordinate axis order.

data.title: Use libsquish to decompress DXT textures.
data.body:
Also ensure that save_png doesn't modify the image.

Removed the broken decompressor in the process.

data.title: Make error handling more convenient (2.1)
data.body:
~~Implemented now as `__builtin_trap()` for GCC/Clang and `__debugbreak()` for MSVC, which are the recommended means of stopping a program on an unrecoverable situation.~~

~~Some  `_TRAP`-suffixed error macros added so this can be reused plus removing the need of double checks. `GENERATE_TRAP` is implemented as well.~~

~~__IMPORTANT!!!__~~

~~I'm starting to think that for 2.1, which is widely in production, the trap stuff may be too aggresive. The former solution (though being undefined behavior) helps masking bugs that may start to be uncovered if this PR is merged as it is now, making games crash when they were running with not noticeable problems so far.~~

~~Maybe for 2.1 we should just raise the perceived severity of the error situations by adding _SEVERE_ or something like that to the messages printed on these situations.~~

~~For _master_ it's fine because it allows precisely to bring those bugs to the surface so they can get a correct solution, specially now it's still unstable.~~

Current status: finally I think that for 2.1 replacing returning a null reference by a trap may break current projects. The classic way is undefined behavior, but can help games keep running instead of crashing. For _master_ it's different since we have there a good chance of actually fixing bugs before stability.

I've named the helpers `PRAY_*` (because anything can happen). They make the code cleaner as the condition doesn't need to be written twice and they encapsulate the null dereferencing stuff. They print the error message with a leading _SEVERE_ which at least differentiates an otherwise fatal error from the handleable ones.

Plus transient avoidance of the flood of warnings emitted by Clang when checking `this` for `NULL`.
~~Plus removal of the pointless `while(0)` loop in some error macros.~~

data.title: Implement well-defined handling of unrecoverable errors
data.body:
Implemented now as `__builtin_trap()` for GCC/Clang and `__debugbreak()` for MSVC, which are the recommended means of stopping a program on an unrecoverable situation.

~~Some  `_TRAP`-suffixed~~ Some  `CRASH_`-prefixed error macros added so this can be reused plus removing the need of double checks:

- `CRASH_COND`
- `CRASH_BAD_INDEX`
- `CRASH_NOW`

`GENERATE_TRAP` is implemented as well, but not intended for direct usage.

Plus transient avoidance of the flood of warnings emitted by Clang when checking `this` for `NULL`.
~~Plus removal of the pointless `while(0)` loop in some error macros.~~

Fixes #8754.

data.title: Rework warning levels
data.body:
Now you have: _extra_, _all_ (the default), _moderate_ and _no_.
The old _yes_ option is still supported for compatibility, but a warning about deprecation will be printed and _all_ will be assumed.

The different options will translate to the following:

- MSVC:
    - _extra_ -> `/Wall` (implies `/W4`)
    - _all_ -> `/W3` + disable non-essential (*)
    - _moderate_ -> `/W2` + disable non-essential (*)
    - _no_ -> `/w`

- GCC/Clang:
    - _extra_ -> `-Wall -Wextra`
    - _all_ -> `-Wall`
    - _moderate_ -> `-Wall -Wno-unused`
    - _no_ -> `-w`

(*) = Truncations, narrowing conversions...: `/wd4267 /wd4244 /wd4305 /wd4800`

This can probably be more fine-tuned, but in the meantime it improves the current state of things substantially, with that _TODO_ promising more options than on/off.

data.title: Rework warning levels (2.1)
data.body:
Now you have: _extra_, _all_ (the default), _moderate_ and _no_.
The old _yes_ option is still supported for compatibility, but a warning about deprecation will be printed and _all_ will be assumed.

The different options will translate to the following:

- MSVC:
    - _extra_ -> `/Wall` (implies `/W4`)
    - _all_ -> `/W3` + disable non-essential (*)
    - _moderate_ -> `/W2` + disable non-essential (*)
    - _no_ -> `/w`

- GCC/Clang:
    - _extra_ -> `-Wall -Wextra`
    - _all_ -> `-Wall`
    - _moderate_ -> `-Wall -Wno-unused`
    - _no_ -> `-w`

(*) = Truncations, narrowing conversions...: `/wd4267 /wd4244 /wd4305 /wd4800`

This can probably be more fine-tuned, but in the meantime it improves the current state of things substantially, with that _TODO_ promising more options than on/off.

data.title: Allow custom CCFLAGS for iPhone builds (2.1)
data.body:
Plus disable exceptions by default since that's the norm for Godot.

Keeping the option in case anyone needs them, but removing that "playbook" mention, possibly inherited from the BlackBerry build.

data.title: Editor crashes upon creating a new animation in the animation player node.
data.body:
I've decided to go on ahead and report my first potential bug: that the animation player is faulty. 
Upon creating a new animation with the animation player node, the editor simply crashes. I don't think i need to write the steps to reproduce, just try to create a new animation.

Also the textbox to name your new animation is overlapping with dialog text. Clicking OK to create your animation will then crash everything.

My apologies if this issue was already reported i don't know how to use github's search bar apparently.

data.title: pan/zoom modifier in 2d
data.body:
In 3d mode there are settings for the pan modifier.
would be cool to also have them in 2d

data.title: Fix InputEvent actions.
data.body:
The `InputEvent::is_action(pressed|released)` methods weren't implemented yet.
Also fixed a typo in `InputDefault` that prevented `Input.is_action(pressed|released)` from working.

Fixes #8914

data.title: Make OS.get_locale() returns same value
data.body:
current OS.get_locale() returns

platform | returns
----- | -----
x11, Android | en_US, en_GB, ko_KR
OSX | en-US, en-GB, ko-KR
iOS, Windows | en, ko

with this PR

platform | returns
----- | -----
x11, Android, OSX, iOS | en_US, en_GB, ko_KR
Windows | en, ko

tried to do with Windows too, but I'm not familiar with it.
I wish somebody checks for Windows.

data.title: GDScript: Use "is" keyword for type checking.
data.body:
Replaces the `extends` keyword with `is` in the context of testing for type compatibility.
`extends` is still used for declaring class inheritance.

Example:

```gdscript
extends Node2D

func _input(ev):
    if ev is InputEventKey:
	print("yay, key event")
```

data.title: Unable to load .fnt fonts (error: "not a resource")
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 17.04 - Godot 98a329670227c726a5d7a196e5cba8dbdd54301b and later

**Issue description:**
Godot is unable to load .fnt fonts anymore


**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a text node (such as "Label")
- Attempt to  load a .fnt file previously working on 9079ef46e72bc9738659a7399e4574e3ae186b38 and older commit)
- Godot refuse to load font (not a resource), node that had previously font loaded can't be loaded with fonts (which need to be removed)


**Link to minimal example project:**
[newpro.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1032292/newpro.zip)
this project loads fine in 9079ef46e72bc9738659a7399e4574e3ae186b38 but not in 98a329670227c726a5d7a196e5cba8dbdd54301b and later commits

data.title: Editor shortcuts aren't displayed

(using the current tip)

In the Shortcuts tab of the Editor Settings dialog, no shortcuts are displayed (other than the ones that aren't set).

data.title: PathEditorPlugin gizmo doesn't work with a single point
data.body:
It seems to be rooted at `Mesh::add_surface_from_arrays`, which no longer likes an array with a single point in it. The error is:

```
ERROR: mesh_add_surface_from_arrays: Condition ' array_len == 0 ' is true.
   At: servers/visual_server.cpp:827.

ERROR: add_surface_from_arrays: Condition ' len == 0 ' is true.
   At: scene/resources/mesh.cpp:329.

ERROR: mesh_surface_set_material: Index p_surface out of size (mesh->surfaces.size()).
   At: drivers/gles3/rasterizer_storage_gles3.cpp:2807.
```


Equivalent function in Godot 2.1 is happy with a single point apparently.

data.title: asin() acos() crash on system
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015)

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

these make godot editor quit unexpectedly


**Steps to reproduce:**



**Link to minimal example project:**

Just create simple codes

extends Node2D

func_ready():
     var simple=asin(10.0)

      
OR


extends Node2D

func _ready():
    var simple=acos(10.0)

data.title: 3.0 some weird things with viewports
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Only tried this on Mac so far, Godot 3.0 todays master

**Issue description:**
Trying to get my stereo camera implementation ported over. Only one of the two viewports ends up being rendered. Also after a few minutes the first viewport stops being updated.
Finally, resizing the viewport doesn't seem to either resize the render texture or how much of the render texture ends up being rendered too.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create two viewports setup as render targets. Add separate cameras to them. Output them with sprites, oly one renders.

**Link to minimal example project:**
https://www.dropbox.com/s/bnuz655it947682/Test-viewports-3.0.zip?dl=0

data.title: Proposal: Add help menu
data.body:
Proposal to add a help menu to Godot. The built-in help is easy to access but many users never find out the rest of the useful websites we have online. This would basically be a way to provide easy shortcuts to said websites.

Right now the structure is as follows:

- class browser (just because it would be strange not to have the built-in stuff too ;))
- online docs : link to docs.godotengine.org
- Q&A : link to q&a site
- Issue Tracker : link to github
- Community : link to https://godotengine.org/community

Optionally, community could be a submenu with direct links to facebook, reddit, twitter, etc...

![help](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1642015/26492544/96e47d52-420c-11e7-8d9c-46d5cfca5cb8.gif)

WDYT?

data.title: Add settings to pan canvas editor instead of zoom with mouse/touchpad scrolling
data.body:
This feature is mainly designed for developers who uses touchpad instead of mouse, and want to scroll instead of zoom. Every macOS developers will like it since it feels intuitive.

2 new settings are added to `2d_editor`:

1. `scroll_to_pan`: turn on to use mouse/touchpad scroll to pan canvas item editor view instead of zoom
2. `pan_speed`: use this value to change scroll speed

data.title: [2.1] Fix item list scroll speed
data.body: Remove the extra `set_val` action after the proper one, so the right scroll value wont get overrided any more.

data.title: [Feature Request] "zero in" node position button/option
data.body: I don't know if I'm the only one who would find this useful, but since it seems to such a common task to "zero in" a node's position relative to its parent, especially when using a lot of drag and drop, wouldn't it be nice to have a button or right-click menu entry to quickly set a node's position to zero (i.e. relative to its parent) instead of having to change 2 or 3 values to do the same thing?
